title: Tuesday, 27th February, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:05 am

Hi -- yes, sorry, late again.

Soundbuy Morning
Nately Ahoy
rwl Hi
GBKrona Hola
Blank canvas good morning everyone

Mostly due to news and trains. There's a lot of the former and not not many of the latter.

Viking Hi
Swedish Chef Morning all. I’m having a packet of crisps for dinner tonight.
h1 Good morning! :) Interserve plc spiking. Cant see any news on my side.

So ........ do we start with the 20% mover or the 80% one?

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 1,334, up 228.5 (+20.68%), High: 1,355, Low: 1,300, Volume: 8.27m

BornCynic Morning
Provident Financial PLC (PFG:LSE): Last: 1,015, up 427 (+72.62%), High: 1,100, Low: 697.00, Volume: 5.79m

The second one, I guess. Because it's the one people seem to be struggling most with.

Shinshin Prov has to be the more painful day, no ?
andyalan10 Good morning, any Drax grey would be nice. They've admitted December's outage was a "small fire".
Nately Has PFG suddenly become a good business?
Shinshin It was consensus "going to breach, going under, CVA, short your boots"
Manxish Morning
11:09 am
BE11:09am

So .......... to quote myself yesterday .....

BE11:09am

The first obvious point is that we don't know where the FCA investigation is going to land, and we assume neither does Provident.

It'd be kinda awkward if the FCA gave Provident highly price sensitive information and Provident communicated that to shareholders without telling the market! Ha! Imagine!

BE11:10am

Ha! Imagine!

11:10 am
BE11:10am

So ... what exactly has happened here?

Swedish Chef @nately Usury is always good business - if it’s done right.
BE11:11am

What it looks like is that Provident managed privately to get an indication of the fine size from the FCA, then sounded out shareholders for a rights issue as well as getting underwriting in place etc, and coordinated both the fine and the cash call announcements to go on results day.

BE11:12am

But, clearly, the FCA's going to be careful with price sensitive data and anyone being sounded out on the rights issue would have been wall crossed. So there'd be no chance of them, for example, talking to the Sunday Telegraph .......

RA hey kids
11:12 am
BE11:12am

...... It all seems quite intricate, though, right? All quite tricky to choreograph.

red @BEfinancial mkts are all about insider and priviledged info sadly
BE11:13am

Kudos to the FCA to have so many people in on what looks like highly sensitive information. Because, to get underwriting in place etc, there must've been a lot of people on the inside.

Pharma Excellent post by Robert Smith on HNA/Deutsche bank
BE11:14am

Anyway, let's get some "line in the sand" stuff up.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Here's Panmure.

BE11:15am

Overall, the settlement should draw a line under the sand and help focus on the underlying business which not so long ago delivered RoE of c35%. We forecast FY2019E RoTE will recover to 25.8% (up from 12% in FY2017).

Deep Breath everyone... "Line under the sand"? nice
BE11:15am

And Citi.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

We view today’s public drawing of a line in the sand as positive. Shareholders, and prospective investors, may now get back to appraising the group’s activities on an ongoing basis with full scope to make an informed investment decision. In future, the group aims to achieve a ~10% RoA (Return on Assets) with receivables growth for the group of between 5-10% through the cycle and a targeted dividend cover of ~1.4x (70% payout ratio). So, the receivables book will be smaller as a result of the home credit changes but, importantly, the group will move down the risk spectrum as it targets more sustainable growth whilst still generating a good RoA and providing stable returns to shareholders.

Shinshin @BE not to argue against your underlying point, but they could have touted the underwrite around at the full 500m, no ?
BE11:16am

That's the theme here. Drawing lines in, or possibly under, sand.

Mouselet Good morning
rise2010 Never seen such a rise on a rights issue like Provident today. Must be allot of short covering
red Still very big issue of execution risk.
Deep Breath everyone... Corus rights issue of old - seem to recall it went up big time
BE11:17am

(@Shinshin: indeed. We talked a time yesterday about having standby underwriting available. That really doesn't look to be what's happened though, does it?)

Lemmy underwriting a deep discount RI = money for old rope
Nately Woodford must be relieved.
11:17 am
BE11:18am

And Numis's James Hamilton, who's a huge bull on this thing.

wayneJ @Pharma - agreed - fascinating - I thought in some jurisdictions a lack of transparency on ownership of shares means loss of votes. Question here is whether the shares are held in HNA's name or the bank that is providing the financing....
red @rise2010you have to take into account yest fall, plus we are still barely half of what the shares stood prior to the summer collapse from 20 quid.
BE11:19am

Management guidance is for a return to profit for the Home Credit business in 2019 and the operating performance of that division continues to improve. With the ROP issue behind Provident we hope the market will focus on the strength of the business units and their fundamental value.

The end game: Provident has category killer businesses that, on a look-through basis, are worth c.£3bn. The market value including the £330m right proceeds is about £1.2bn a clear Buy.

BE11:19am

ROTR mentions the short out there ......

11:20 am

.... Now, the easy way to crush shorts in these circumstances is to make the stock go ex-rights immediately.

Kijana Anyone with thoughts on Comcast Sky bid? Doesn't seem like Fox is going to get into a bidding war with Comcast, especially as they've already indicated their intention to sell the stake to Disney? Is this a trojan horse attempt by Comcast to bring all Fox assets Disney bought back into play, or will Disney just leave Sky for Comcast
BE11:21am

They haven't pulled that trick so, while I guess there's a fair bit of Scorchedfingers out there among the 20% or so free float on loan, we can't put today's rerating down solely to a squeeze.

chad_john Kijana - that is the, almost literal, $64m dollar question.
chad_john (two 'dollars' there)
Kijana haha
Pseudonym @Nately I'm sure Woodford will be fine regardless. It's the fundamental problem with overpaid fund managers.
Pseudonym No skin in the game.
BE11:22am

So ...... let's go with drawing lines. In sand. Through sand. Under sand. Whatever.

undefined

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 1,334, up 228.5 (+20.68%), High: 1,355, Low: 1,300, Volume: 8.42m

Comcast offering £12,50, plus the divi due in April.

Several curious details in there though. The first is that it's only 50% approval.

Kijana chad_john Clearly the market is expecting a bidding war, I'd expect Fox to confer with Disney and just say, ok all yours Comcast...I'm not sure Disney is as excited about the Sky assets as Comcast is, even with the Football Rights acquisition

The second is that it's a Rule 2.4 rather than a Rule 2.7. As in, possible offer rather than a formal one.

chad_john I think Disney need Sky personally
urgeview Could you cover Coats as well ? TIA.
Forester @pharma looked at HNA last year for various reasons - whilst could not find anything "bad", the sheer complexity and lack of visibility rang all our old "tide goes out" alarm bells so we passed on the opportunity concerned.
red think he will try to be as uneventful as poss. options mkts certainly now pricing in much move on fx. about a half point move on euro or yen dollar pairs.
chad_john @BE Is it a 2.4 only because it's conditional on the 50% +1 share acceptance?
11:27 am
BE11:27am

It's all quite cleverly constructed by Comcast. They've gone hostile, effectively, and gone clean straight to the market rather than faff about with approaches and such.

BE11:29am

(@chad_john: nope. 2.4 is based on the pre-conditions not the structure, IIRC.)

chad_john Ta
BE11:29am

What happens next? Well, everyone seems to assume that Fox will go in again.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Jefferies has a very good, comprehensive, and dizzyingly complicated summary.

BE11:30am

We believe that Comcast ownership of Sky represents a much less controversial outcome for the CMA and UK government. Comcast’s approach could even encourage the CMA to adopt a harder line in its response to the Sky News remedies submitted recently by FOX. Comcast offers no media plurality concerns, in our view, and stresses its commitment to Sky’s London HQ, to content production in the UK and to Sky News.

FOX could in principle elect to accept Comcast’s offer. In that event, Comcast has reserved the right to switch from a simple takeover offer (requiring 50% plus 1 share acceptance) to a Scheme of Arrangement (requiring 75% approval of all Sky shareholders, including Murdoch Family Trust as they are not setting up this Scheme).

More likely is that FOX will raise its offer well above £12.50, in our view. This would give unaffiliated Sky shareholders an incentive to hold out and see if CMA approval of FOX-Sky is forthcoming. The problem for FOX of merely cashing in its Sky stake is not that this derails DIS-FOX (we understand that there is no exit route for DIS, or no impact on offer value, if Sky assets are sold before DIS takes charge). Instead, the issue for FOX would be that if it sold out of Sky only then to find that DIS-FOX were blocked, FOX would be left as a sub-scale collection of mainly US assets with India as the only material international exposure.

BE11:30am

Likely DIS response, in our view, will be to table a direct offer to Sky shareholders. DIS CEO has described Sky as the ‘crown jewel’ asset among the FOX operations he is seeking to acquire. Just as with Comcast, adding more international distribution (direct to consumer) and content production is strategic to countering Netflix, Amazon, etc. A counter-bid from DIS would avoid the regulatory complexities/delays in much the same way as the Comcast approach.

A higher Comcast offer would then be feasible, in our view. This is likely to be justifiable on the basis of synergies (not mentioned in today’s press release) and the aforementioned strategic need to bolster scale and growth. With Comcast's £131bn market cap dwarfing Sky’s £22bn market cap (at £12.50/share), there is potential to go higher, in our view.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

You don't need me to point out that Sky's trading miles through the terms, so we're assuming a counter of some kind.

BE11:32am

Citi .....

BE11:32am

We have consistently argued that Sky is
worth more than the current offer. To be specific, we have used two valuation
methodologies to reach our ‘standalone’ valuation for Sky: first, a DCF-based valuation analysis using a discount rate of 9% and a LT growth assumption of 3% drives an implied fair value of 1,309p. The second is a sum-of-the-parts analysis looking at the valuations of the different divisions on a separate basis, which drives an implied fair value of 1,324p. With the potential for a bidding war, we think £13 per share (or more) is no longer the pipedream it was once considered.

Otter Hello brave and handsome internet friends
11:33 am
BE11:33am

And via the Olivetree events folk .....

BE11:33am

All signs point to this announcement being genuinely in competition with Fox & Disney, the market is right to be pricing in real competitive tension now. The press had us believe that Comcast tried to buy Fox’s asset package but was defeated by a more deliverable Disney - the nature of today’s statement shows that Comcast do have a genuine desire to own Sky and they think Disney do too. We have all been musing for some weeks as to whether Disney REALLY wanted Sky, or whether in reality it just came as part of a bigger package – the structure of Comcast’s offer would seem to suggest they really do. Not only is it now clear that Comcast obviously want to own Sky, that they have conditioned their approach on 50% acceptance suggests that they don’t expect Fox to tender, suggesting that Disney really want the asset.

Kijana @BE Thanks
wayneJ Do the Murdoch trusts end up with different tax positions in a Fox vs a Comcast vs a Dis takeover?
BE11:34am

The body-language here says there is real competitive tension for Sky. Comcast’s timing is interesting, it allows them to start their regulatory filings, which could well conclude at a similar point to a Fox transaction being put in front of Sky shareholders. Comcast’s approach should be very clean, the regulatory backdrop for them should be straightforward, and the 50% acceptance shows that they are happy to own the asset alongside Fox / Disney. Whether Fox/Disney are happy to do the same remains to be seen. The ownership structure of Hulu hasn’t been a tremendous success, but with Disney owning 30% Fox 30% and Comcast 30% there is a precedent here for shared ownership between these groups. Comcast’s remedies with regards to influence over its stake (as a result of the NBC Universal deal) roll off this year, exasperating this further. A curious dynamic to throw into the mix. Expect to see the market continue to model real competitive tension for Sky, all of Comcast’s body language this morning suggests this is the case, rather than some cosy deal behind the scenes. The next move would appear to be Fox Disney’s to make.

December69 - Sceptic Potential to go higher? Based on what
pancakes or waffles To the my more knowledgeable peers here, is the Comcast bid for Sky really about Sky or is it more about disrupting Disney-FOX? Know very little about the situation beyond headlines, but I was under impression Comcast was prev interested in FOX?

So Murdoch family trust will still have same position, because this is Fox being taxed on foreign capital gains which have no liability as per new territorial tax system

With final results largely as expected, it was down to the balance sheet and the revised capital return plan to provide the positive surprise. The new plan will see the payout step up to 235p from 110p, with the extra 125p being paid at the end of March/start of April in 2018/19/20 in conjunction with the 110p being paid in early July. With the yield climbing to a pretty secure 9.4% it is hard not to see the shares going better this morning. We need to run our full model to work out where our new TP climbs to.

Persimmon remains the benchmark for housebuilders in the UK, with leading
operating margins, returns and cash position. This is supported by an attractive buyer profile (the lowest ASP in the sector, 50% of private sales supported by HTB and no London exposure). However, we believe this is reflected in the valuation, with the stock trading on an FY19 EV/IC of 2.4x.

The key announcement is on the Connecting for Growth
programme – this is expected to deliver $25m of savings by 2020,
of which $10m will be reinvested in growth opportunities. In
addition, results were slightly ahead of forecasts and the
company has good momentum going into the current year. As a
result, we are increasing our EPS forecasts by 3% in 2018 rising
to 7% by 2020.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

They're shop.

BE11:56am

The programme is designed to simplify the business, deliver cost savings and
increase investment in growth.
 The company is moving from a country model to a more global platform,
reducing the long-tail of operations and cutting the number of SKUs by one-
third (predominately reducing regional variations). The local management
team structure will move to 10 scalable clusters.
 Gross cost savings (predominately personnel costs) are expected to be $25m by 2020. There will be a $30m exceptional cost to deliver the savings, the majority of which will be charged in 2018.
 $10m of the savings will be reinvested in growth initiatives, which will be focused on innovation, digital and people.
 The net savings are expected to be $5m in 2018 rising to $15m in 2020, which equates to a 100bp improvement in the operating margin.

the company accelerates progress through infill acquisitions and as new product development expands the Performance Materials contribution.
